Motivation 

Mapping the Land-Use Land-Cover (LULC) changes through time is important and desirable in many fields i ecology like to predict the threats or propose effective conservation policies and others (Jetz,Wilcove, Dobson, 2007).

Motivation
 
One interesting database called Land-Use Harmonization (LUH2), provides a set of land-use scenarios  for historical, present and future projections (years from 800 to 2300). The raw data are continuous layers for twelve types called states
```{r LUH2, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, out.width= "60%", paged.print=TRUE, fig.align = "center"}
knitr::include_graphics("https://luh.umd.edu/images/LUH2_logo300.jpg")
```
---
Motivation 
```{r LUH2_2, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, out.width= "40%", paged.print=TRUE, fig.align = "center"}
knitr::include_graphics("https://luh.umd.edu/images/LUH2_logo300.jpg")
```
 - primf: forested primary land
 - primn: non-forested primary land
 - secdf: potentially forested secondary land
 - secdn: potentially non-forested secondary land
 - pastr: managed pasture
 - range: rangeland
 - urban: urban land
 - c3ann: C3 annual crops
 - c3per: C3 perennial crops
 - c4ann: C4 annual crops
 - c4per: C4 perennial crops
 - c3nfx: C3 nitrogen-fixing crops

Issue

However this data in provided in netcdf format, that is not user friendely for ecologist. 

---
Main goal 

1- Redistribute the data in Tagged Image Format File (.tif extention) that is more commom format used in ecology analysis. 

2- Created a new data from these 12 states.

---
How?

I build a R scripts for : 
1- Extract one by one layer 
2- Save each single layer (which is a continuous data) as a TIF format, 
3- Perfomer a analysis to create a LULC categorical data that in a new data produced here.
4- Validadtion of LULC new data (in porgress)

```{r workflow, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, paged.print=TRUE, out.width = "65%"}

knitr::include_graphics("https://github.com/Tai-Rocha/LUH2_Data/blob/master/doc/Figures/LUH2%20_LULC.png?raw=true")

```
